entries.full_text:
Chapter IV 
 
 
Fish Consumption: A Paradox 
of Good Health 
 
 
Johnny O. Ogunji∗ 
Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture, Ebonyi State University  
P.M.B 053 Abakaliki Nigeria 
 
 
Abstract 
 
Fish is an important part of a healthy diet. There are many nutritional benefits from 
including fish in the diet. Fish are low in saturated fats and contain high quality protein 
and omega-3 fatty acids (a class of fatty-acids that are essential for cell development and 
have other beneficial health effects). Fish also supply a number of vitamins and minerals 
including calcium, iron, zinc, vitamin A, niacin, vitamin B6 and vitamin D. Eating fish 
can contribute to a healthy heart and a child’s proper growth and intellectual 
development. Studies have shown that eating fish regularly (such as twice per week) can 
reduce the chance of death from a heart attack. However, concerns have long existed 
about whether fish are safe to eat due to the trace amounts of chemicals that may be 
present in fish tissue. Low levels of natural and man-made chemicals are in the water in 
which fish live. Three of the chemicals that can accumulate in fish tissue are mercury, 
polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and chlordane among others. Human health studies 
have indicated that reproductive function may be disrupted by exposure to these 
chemicals; neurobehavioral and developmental deficits occur in newborns and continue 
through school-aged children who had in utero been exposed. Other systemic effects 
(e.g., self-reported liver disease and diabetes, and effects on the thyroid and immune 
systems) are associated with elevated serum levels; and increased cancer risks are also 
associated with exposures. This article examines the economic importance of fish 
consumption in relation to good health and looks at the potentials of producing safe fish 
through aquaculture. 
 
                                                 
 
∗ Correspondence: Tel. 002348067558863 Email Ogunjijo@yahoo.com. 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Johnny O. Ogunji 
78 
 
1. World Fish Production and Consumption 
 
According to FAO (2002) global production from capture fisheries, aquaculture and the 
food fish supply is currently the highest on record and remains very significant for global 
food security, providing more than 15 percent of total animal protein supplies. Global capture 
of fish for food jumped from 44 million tonnes in 1973 to 65 million tonnes in 1997 (Delgago 
et al., 2003). The global production in 2005 was 141.4 million tonnes. Capture fisheries 
contributed 95.6 million tonnes in 2000 but decreased to 93.3 million tonnes around 2005. 
Aquaculture on the other hand increased from 35.5 million tonnes in 2000 to 48.1 million 
tonnes in 2005 (FAO 2006a, b).  
Fish and fisheries market has become one of the world’s fastest growing international 
commodity markets. The global trade value has grown from USD 6 billion in 1980 to USD 
56 billion in 2001 (Scholz 2005). More than 200 countries supply the global market with 
more than 800 commercially relevant species of fish crustacean, mollusc and squid. The 
product variety ranges from canned tuna to boneless salmon fillet, salted herring, dried cod, 
frozen fish fingers, smoked mackerel, and life lobsters, to oysters in sauce or sardines for 
processing into animal feed.  
In 1970 the apparent world average food fish per caput consumption was estimated at 
10.9 kg/year. It increased to 13.6 in 1989 and declined to 13.0 Kg/year in 1993 (Josupeit 
1994). Based on the information available in August 2006, FAO has calculated the apparent 
world average food fish per caput consumption in 2007 as 16.4 Kg/year (FAO 2007). It can 
be seen that the change in growth has not been continues but that changes have existed. 
Interestingly current data has been the highest for quite a long time. 
The per-caput fish supply is currently however, not equally distributed by economic 
grouping like in the past. Developed countries record a per-caput fish supply of 23.7 Kg/year, 
Industrialised countries – 29.5 Kg/year; developing countries – 14.5 Kg/year and low-income 
food – deficit countries – 13.9 Kg/year. The value for developing countries has increased 
from 6.2 Kg/year in 1970 to 9.4 Kg/year in 1990 (Josupeit 1994). This progressive increase is 
encouraging but calls for concerted effort to produce and supply safe fish for good health.  
Western Europe is the main fish consuming region among developed countries with a 
fish per – caput supply 30.5 Kg/year. Faeroe Island and Iceland situated in this region 
recorded the highest per-caput fish supply as follows: Faeroe Island 87.5 and Iceland 91.4 
Kg/year. Northern America 22.7 Kg/year and Oceania (Australia and New Zealand) 22.9 
Kg/year recorded lower supply. Maldives has over the years become a country with highest 
per-caput fish supply in the world. It was 130 kg/year in 1990 and 190Kg/year currently 
(FAO 2007). Practically fish is the only food that does not have to be imported and it is a 
staple food in this country. 
The foregoing has shown the increased interest of humans to consume fish. The issue to 
be dealt with is the safety of the fish consumed and how to produce safe fish. Before dwelling 
on that it is good to assess the benefits derived by man from consuming fish. 
 
 
 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Fish Consumption: A Paradox of Good Health 
79
2. Benefits of Fish Consumption 
 
Research has revealed that fish (finfish or shellfish) is a healthy food. This very 
important attribute of fish is linked to the type of fatty acid fish contains. Fatty acids are 
components of lipids. For clarity, better understanding and appreciation of the facts it is good 
to briefly look at how the fatty acids are categorised.  
According to New (1987) fatty acids are given a common name but are also, besides their 
straightforward chemical formula, given a specific numerical designation, such as 14:0; 20:1; 
18:3n-3; 18:2n-6; 20:4n-6; 22:5n-6; or 22:6n-3. This nomenclature refers to the length of the 
carbon chain in the molecule, the number of carbon-carbon double bonds present and the 
position of the first double bond. This can be illustrated by the chemical formulae of some of 
the fatty acids mentioned above. The methyl group is shown in the formulae below as CH3.  
In the designation 20: n-6, for example, '20' means that there are 20 carbon atoms in the 
chain. '4' means that there are four carbon-carbon double bonds (the double bond is shown as 
a = sign and the carbon atom is shown as C). n-6 means that the first double bond, numbering 
from the methyl (CH3) end, occurs after the sixth carbon atom in the chain. Myristic acid 
(14:0) has fourteen carbon atoms but no C=C double bonds. Arachidic acid (20:0) also has no 
double bonds. Linolenic acid (18:3n-3) has eighteen carbon atoms and three double bonds, 
the first of which appears on the third carbon atom. Linoleic acid (18:2n-6) has two double 
bonds and the first occurs on the sixth carbon atom and so on. 
Those fatty acids which have their first double bond on the third carbon atom are known 
as the 'n-3' series or the 'linolenic' series after the name of the fatty acid in the series with 18 
carbon atoms in its chain. Similarly, those which have their first double bond on the sixth 
carbon atom are known as the 'n-6' series or the 'linoleic series.  
 
 
 
 
Saturated fatty acids are those without any double bonds. Monosaturated fatty acids are 
those with only one double bond, while those with more than one double bond are known as 
poly-unsaturated fatty acids. Those with fewer double bonds are referred to as 'more 
saturated' than those with a greater number. The n-3 series and n-6 series fatty acids, and the 
n-7 and n-9 fatty acids are all members of the group known as polyunsaturated fatty acids, 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Johnny O. Ogunji 
80 
because they have more than one double bond. Sometimes these are referred to as PUFA's for 
short. Members of this group which have many (4 or more) double bonds are sometimes 
referred to as higher unsaturated fatty acids (HUFA'S).  
Evidence from several research works, including animal – experimental, observational, 
and clinical studies have further confirmed the importance of fish consumption in human 
nutrition. Two long chain n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs), eicosapentaenoic acid 
(EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), have been identified as the likely active 
constituents. 
The role of n-3 fatty acids in growth and development as well as in health and disease—
particularly coronary heart disease (CHD) is currently one of the fastest growing research 
areas in nutritional science. As a result, knowledge of these essential PUFAs has grown 
significantly (Simopoloulos 1999). Benefits from n-3 fatty acids were first noticed in 
epidemiological studies among Greenland Inuit. The rarity of ischemic heart disease 
(characterized by narrowed heart arteries) in this Eskimo population was attributed to their 
traditional, EPA-rich diet of marine animals and fish. Moreover, Eskimo consumption of n – 
3 fatty acids was low compared to the typical Danish diet (Bang et al., 1980). This 
observation has led to several epidemiological and observational studies of men and women, 
who regularly consume fish, showing similar heart health results (Kris-Etherton 2002). 
Cardiovascular benefits from n-3 fatty acid consumption have been documented in several 
prospective studies and randomized clinical trials (Harris and Isley, 2001; Kris-Etherton et 
al., 2002; Von Schacky et al., 2002; AHRQ 2004). 
Von Schacky et al., 2002 in a clinical trial found that patients who were given fish oil 
concentrate for two years had lower triglyceride levels and minimal artery blockage when 
compared to those receiving a placebo. These results showed that consuming n-3 fatty acids 
daily may reduce the risk of abnormal thickening of arteries due to fatty deposits on arterial 
inner walls (atherosclerosis). n-3 PUFAs influence several cardio vascular risk factors 
(Mozaffarian, 2006). Effects occur within weeks of intake and may result from altered 
membrane fluidity and receptor responses following incorporation of n-3 PUFAs into cell 
membranes (Clandinin et al., 1991; Feller and Gawrisch 2005) and direct binding of n-3 
PUFAs to intracellular receptors regulating gene transcription (Vanden 2004). 
The heterogeneity of the effects of fish or fish oil intake on cardiovascular outcomes is 
likely related to varying dose and time responses of effects on the risk factors. At typical 
dietary intakes, antiarrhythmic effects predominate, reducing risk of sudden death and CHD 
death within weeks. At higher doses, maximum antiarrhythmic effects have been achieved, 
but other physiologic effects may modestly impact other clinical outcomes (possibly 
requiring years to produce clinical benefits). For instance, nonfatal myocardial infarction may 
not be significantly affected by lower doses or shorter durations of intake but may be 
modestly reduced by higher doses or prolonged intake (e.g., 1.8 g/d for 5 years17) 
(Mozaffarian and Rimm 2006). 
A meta-analysis of studies on diabetes and fish oils found a 30 percent reduction in 
patient triglyceride levels—particularly among subjects with Type I diabetes. This is 
noteworthy, considering that the high cardiovascular mortality rate of people with diabetes 
has been partially attributed to increased triglyceride concentrations in the blood (Friedberg 
1998). It has been suggested that n-3 fatty acids have a protective mechanism of reducing the 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Fish Consumption: A Paradox of Good Health 
81
risk of irregular heartbeats (De Lorgeril et al., 1999; Marchioli et al., 2002; Singh et al., 
2002). Marchioli et al. (2002) demonstrated that even a small amount (1 g/d) of n-3 fatty 
acids is effective in reducing overall mortality and risk of cardiac death by 20 percent and 45 
percent, respectively. 
Omega-3 fatty acids are also shown to be beneficial at various life stages and with 
several health conditions. DHA is naturally found in breast milk and has been shown to 
support the visual and cognitive development in infants. Various infant formulas now contain 
DHA along with arachidonic acid (20:4n-6; got from eating meat, poultry, and eggs) to more 
closely mimic breast milk. Evidence has also emerged showing benefits from n-3 fatty acid 
consumption in health conditions such as, depression, cancer, lupus, and asthma. A cross-
sectional study in Australia showed an inverse association between age-related maculopathy 
(ARM) — a leading cause of blindness in older adults — and fish consumption. Individuals 
who ate fish more than once per week reduced their risk of having ARM by half compared to 
those who ate fish less than once per month. Patients with rheumatoid arthritis, who received 
fish oil supplements in addition to background medication, had a significant decrease in the 
number of tender joints and morning stiffness (Reifen et al., 1998; Kremer 2000; Smith et 
al., 2000; Koumenis et al., 2003; Jho et al., 2004; Suzuki et al., 2004). The continued study of 
n-3 fatty acids will lead to further understanding of their effects on development, health, and 
disease risk reduction. 
Fish also supply a number of vitamins and minerals including calcium, iron, zinc, 
vitamin A, niacin, vitamin B6 and vitamin D. Eating fish can contribute to a child’s proper 
growth and intellectual development (IDPH 2005). It lowers the risk of some cardiovascular 
outcomes (Mozaffarian and Rimm 2006), dementia, (Morris et al., 2005) neuropsychiatric 
disorders (Peet and Stokes, 2005; Young and Conquer 2005) and inflammatory disorders 
(Mori and Beilin, 2004; Mickleborough et al., 2006).  
 
 
3. Fish Contamination by Chemicals and Effect 
of Consumption 
 
There have been concerns whether fish are safe to be eaten due to the trace amounts of 
chemicals that may be present in fish tissue. Low levels of natural and man-made chemicals 
are in the water in which fish live. Three major chemicals that can accumulate in fish tissue to 
produce deleterious effect on human are mercury, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and 
chlordane. It is important to trace how these contaminants get into the water naturally and 
through pollution. 
The Joint Group of Experts on Scientific Aspects of Marine Pollution (GESAMP) (1980) 
defined marine pollution as "the introduction by man, directly or indirectly of substances or 
energy (e.g. heat) into the marine environment (including estuaries) resulting in such 
deleterious effects as harm to living resources, hazards to human health, hindrance to marine 
activities including fisheries, impairment of quality for use of seawater and reduction of 
amenities". This definition, although given with special consideration to marine water will be 
applied here generally to all water or aquatic environment (marine and fresh water). 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Johnny O. Ogunji 
82 
Very important pollutants are heavy metals, that include mercury (Hg), cadmium (Cd), 
lead (Pb), chromium (Cr), copper (Cu) and zinc (Zn). Their natural sources are by water 
runoffs from areas with rocks containing these heavy metals. The man made sources are from 
the production plants of these metals as dusts and water runoffs; the dumping of refuse from 
factories and workshops which use these chemicals; from domestic waste through improper 
disposal of batteries and other such materials; weathering of Zinc roofs; Cu and Cd plating 
from paper producing factories and agriculture, these metals are also found in fungal agents 
for pulp and seed. They are also found in sewage sludge. Pb is also generated from vehicle 
exhaust for it is a petrol additive.  
Heavy metals tend to be absorbed to mud particles and thus vanish into the bottom of 
lakes, rivers and sea. As long as these "sinks" are not disturbed the heavy metals are then no 
longer bio-available. However, these pollutants are taken up directly from the water and they 
accumulate in food chain. Among solutes present in surface and ground water, heavy metals 
in their ionic forms belong to a category of pollutants. Their accumulation in the tissues of an 
organism can result in chronic illness. Being non-biodegradable, they can be concentrated 
along the food chain, producing their toxic effects at points often far removed from the 
source of pollution (Alam et. al., 1983).  
Halogenated hydrocarbons are another major group of water pollutants. These are 
organic compounds, where hydrogen (H) has been (partly or fully) substituted by chlorine 
and/or fluorine. Their major sources are pesticides, technical fluids like hydraulic "oil" and 
brake fluid, cooling "oil" and softener in plastic materials, some plastic materials (PVC) and 
dry cleaning fluid. Pesticides can be classified on the basis of their intended pest targets. 
These categories are given by Entomological Society of America (ESA) (1980), as follows:- 
 
• 
Fungicides, used to protect crop plants and animals from fungal pathogens e.g. 
organometalic compounds of mercury and tin chlorophenolics as tri- tetra- and 
penta- chlorophenol. 
• 
Herbicides, used to kill weedy plants, so as to release desired crop plant competition 
chloroaliphatics such as dalapon and trichloroacetate.  
• 
Insecticides, used to kill insects pest and vectors of deadly animal diseases such as 
malaria, yellow fever, tripanosomiasis (e.g. the DDT group of chlororinated 
hydrocarbons including DDT, DDDand methoxychlor). 
• 
Acaricides, used to kill mites, which are pests in agriculture and ticks that carry 
encephalitis of human and domestic animals. 
• 
Molluscides are used against snails and slugs that can be important pests of citrus 
groves and vegetables and flower gardens. They are also used to kill aquatic snails 
which are vectors of certain human diseases especially schistosomiasis. Examples 
are ethylene dibromide, dichloropane or dichloropropane.  
• 
Others are rodenticides used for the control of rats, avicides, for the control of birds 
and antibiotics used for control of bacteria caused infections band diseases.  
 
 
 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Fish Consumption: A Paradox of Good Health 
83
Halogenated hydrocarbons are found in water only in low concentrations. They attach 
themselves readily to organic matter, so they are kept within the flood chains for a long time 
until they are eventually degraded. These pollutants are lipophhilic, so they easily get 
dissolved in fat tissue and accumulate in food chain. 
Crude and mineral oil are petroleum products which have become very outstanding water 
pollutants. Crude oil is compounds that occur in liquid form. They are obtained by drilling. 
Through the process of refining, various hydrocarbon fractions are separated by fractional 
distillation. The refined hydrocarbons are referred to as minerals here, and include fuels 
(diesel, kerosene, bunker oil) and all lubricants (engine oil etc). The sources of crude oil 
pollutants into the aquatic environment include; during on-site drilling and production, 
during storage, shipment and processing through spillage or leakage. The source of the 
mineral oils are from processing plants, fuel from tanks are some time washed into water. 
Other times it is during shipment and from all sorts of powered vehicles. Bunker is a very 
heavy fuel used to power big ships, it contains plenty of unusable substances, when it is 
purified on board the vessels, the residual is frequently dumped over board. These more or 
less are the main sources of the present day "tar balls" in the sea. Lubricants dripping from 
vehicles and other engine installations, including used engine oil that are dumped 
indiscriminately are also major sources. Only a small fraction of these pollutants dissolve in 
the water especially the non-aliphatics, which are poisonous.  
From towns and crude oil production sites oil is flushed into the water with rain runoff. 
In a case of oil spill, the oil can cover the water surface. It later disintegrates into tar balls; 
part of it may sink to the bottom and mix there with sediments. At beaches the waves can mix 
oil and water to sticky emulsion referred to as, "chocolate mouse". Some of the oil will be 
deposited on the mud flats.  
Mercury is a naturally occurring element in the environment and is also released into the 
air through industrial pollution. Mercury that falls from the air can accumulate in streams, 
rivers, lakes and the ocean. Mercury is often the contaminant of greatest concern in fish tissue 
world over. It is a reactive heavy metal. In water it is converted by microbial activity into 
organic methylmercury. Inorganic mercury is poorly absorbed following ingestion, and 
elemental mercury does not readily cross tissue barriers. In contrast, methylmercury is readily 
absorbed and actively transported into tissues (EPA 2006). Thus, methylmercury 
bioaccumulates in aquatic food chains and has greater potential toxicity than inorganic 
Mercury (EPA 2005; 2006; RAIS 2006). Concentrations of methylmercury in aquatic species 
depend on levels of environmental contamination and on the predatory nature and lifespan of 
the species. Larger, longer-living predators (eg, swordfish, shark) have higher tissue 
concentrations, while smaller or shorter-lived species (eg, shellfish, salmon) have very low 
concentrations. Preparation methods have little impact on methylmercury content 
(Mozaffarian and Rimm 2006). 
Health effects of very high mercury exposure following occupational or industrial 
accidents are well documented. These include paresthesias, ataxia, and sensory abnormalities 
in adults, and delayed cognitive and neuromuscular development following in utero exposure 
(Gochfeld, 2003). Toxicity appears related to binding of methylmercury to sulfhydryl groups 
of enzymes, ion channels, and receptors, resulting in inhibition of antioxidant systems and 
production of free radicals and reactive oxygen species (NRC 2000).  
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Johnny O. Ogunji 
84 
Neurotoxicity is generally considered the health impact of greatest concern for dietary 
methylmercury intake. High-dose human exposure can result in sensory and motor 
impairment and other adverse impacts, up to and including death. High dose in utero 
exposure can cause mental retardation, cerebral palsy and deafness. There is also some 
evidence suggesting lower-dose exposures can have cardiovascular and immunological 
effects, but good epidemiological data is lacking. There is no argument that high doses of 
methylmercury can have severe health impacts. The question is whether relatively low level 
exposure, such as that incurred by fish consumption, presents more subtle risks such as 
cognitive disabilities, especially for children exposed to low levels in utero and though early 
childhood consumption of mother’s milk and fish. The Iowa Department of Public Health 
(IDPH), using USEPA guidance, determined that all fish containing less than 0.3 ppm 
mercury are safe to consume with no meal restriction. Consumption of up to 1 meal/week of 
fish containing between 0.3 and 1.0 ppm of mercury was safe and fish containing over 1.0 
ppm of mercury should not be eaten (which is consistent with the current mercury FDA 
action level) (IDPH, 2005).  
Chlordane is an organochlorine pesticide that was produced and sold in the United States 
from 1946 through 1987. Chlordane is resistant to breakdown in the environment and has a 
half-life of 10-20 years. Due to known toxicity and potential carcinogenicity, the United 
States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) cancelled registration for all uses of 
chlordane on food crops in 1978. Before 1978, chlordane was used extensively as a lawn and 
garden pesticide and for the control of cutworms in corn. After restrictions were placed on 
usage in 1978, the primary use for chlordane was as a termaticide in building construction. 
Chlordane has been shown to cause liver cancer in mice and rats. USEPA classifies chlordane 
as a "probable" human carcinogen. In 1988, due to continued controversy over its use, the 
USEPA cancelled the registration of all products containing chlordane. Use of existing 
supplies was allowed until April 15, 1988 when both the sale and use of technical chlordane 
were voluntarily suspended. The sale, purchase, and use of chlordane in Iowa were banned as 
of January 1, 1989. The IDPH, using USEPA guidance, determined that all fish containing 
less than 0.6 ppm chlordane are safe to consume with no meal restriction. Consumption of up 
to 1 meal/week of fish containing between 0.6 and 5.0 ppm of chlordane was safe and fish 
containing over 5.0 ppm of chlordane should not be eaten.  
Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) are industrial chemicals that were manufactured in the 
United States from 1929 until 1977 under the trade name Aroclor. Currently, PCBs are not 
produced in the United States, but many products containing PCBs are still in service. 
Dioxins— commonly referring to dibenzodioxins and dibenzofurans—are organochlorine by-
products of waste incineration, paper bleaching, pesticide production, and production of 
polyvinyl chloride plastics. Prior to 1977, PCBs were used in closed electrical systems such 
as capacitors and transformers. Before 1971, PCBs were used in a number of applications, 
including plasticizers, heat transfer fluids, hydraulic fluids, fluids in vacuum pumps and 
compressors, lubricants and wax extenders. Similar to chlordane, PCBs are also 
organochlorine compounds that are resistant to breakdown in the environment. PCBs tend to 
adsorb to sediments or other organic matter in aquatic environments. PCBs are highly 
lipophilic (fat soluble) and accumulate in tissues of fish and other aquatic organisms by a 
factor of 10,000 over concentrations found in ambient waters. PCBs are classified by USEPA 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Fish Consumption: A Paradox of Good Health 
85
as "probable" human carcinogens. The IDPH, using USEPA guidance, determined that all 
fish containing less than 0.2ppm PCBs are safe to consume with no meal restriction. 
Consumption of up to 1 meal/week of fish containing between 0.2 and 2.0ppm of PCBs was 
safe and fish containing over 2.0ppm of PCBs should not be eaten (which is consistent with 
the current PCBs FDA action level) IDPH (2005). 
Animal experiments and some evidence in humans indicate that PCBs and dioxins are 
carcinogenic, possibly related to effects on the aryl hydrocarbon receptor, a transcription 
factor affecting gene expression (WHO 1998). According to Mozaffarian and Rimm (2006) 
multiple congeners (structural variants) of PCBs and dioxins exist. Potential toxicities of 
foods are calculated using toxic equivalence (TEQ): the sum of each congener’s level in the 
food multiplied by that congener’s toxic equivalency factor (standardized against 2,3,7,8-
tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin). In the United States, PCBs comprise 28% and dioxins 72% of 
total TEQ exposure (Schecter et al., 2001). Among adults, major dietary sources of PCBs and 
dioxins are beef, chicken, and pork (34% of total TEQ); dairy products (30%); vegetables 
(22%); fish and shellfish (9%); and eggs (5%). However, a considerable attention has been 
given to fish sources. Dietary sources are similar for children. When PCBs and dioxins were 
measured in farmed and wild salmon (Hites et al., 2004; Hamilton 2005) the levels were 
similar to those in several other foods (WHO 1998).  
Prenatal exposure to PCBs and dioxins has been associated with childhood neuro-
developmental deficits in several (Jacobson and Jacobson 1996; Patandin et al., 1999; Ribas-
Fito et al., 2001; Stewart et al., 2003; Schantz et al., 2003) but not in all the studies (Buck et 
al., 2003). Because most exposure (> 90%) generally comes from meat, dairy, and vegetable 
sources this concern is not specific to fish consumption, particularly since fish also contains 
potentially beneficial DHA. However, women consuming one or more servings per day of 
commercial freshwater fish or consuming locally caught freshwater fish from highly 
contaminated inland sources may be more greatly exposed to PCBs and dioxins (Judd et al., 
2004). It has been reported that the PCB content in fish can be reduced 12% to 40% by 
trimming belly and back fat during filleting and by not consuming the skin (Thannum 2006). 
High contaminant levels are typically measured in unprepared foods, and cooking may 
reduce PCB and dioxin content (Schecter et al., 1998).  
 
 
4. Aquaculture and Aquaculture Production 
 
Aquaculture is the rearing of aquatic organisms under controlled or semi-controlled 
conditions. Thus aquaculture is underwater agriculture. According to the definition used by 
FAO for statistical purposes, aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms including fish, 
molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Farming implies some sort of intervention in the 
rearing process to enhance production, such as regular stocking, feeding, protection from 
predators, etc. Farming also implies individual or corporate ownership of the stock being 
cultivated 
Aquaculture is currently one of the fastest growing food production systems in the world. 
With stagnating yields from many capture fisheries and increasing demand for fish and 
fishery products, expectations for aquaculture to increase its contribution to the world’s 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Johnny O. Ogunji 
86 
production of aquatic food are very high, and there is also hope that aquaculture will continue 
to strengthen its role in contributing to food security and poverty alleviation in many 
developing countries. However, it is also recognized that aquaculture encompasses a very 
wide range of different aquatic farming practices with regards to species (including seaweeds, 
molluscs, crustaceans, fish and other aquatic species groups), environments and systems 
utilized. The systems have very distinct resource use patterns involved. They offer a wide 
range of options for diversification of avenues for enhanced food production and income 
generation in many rural and peri-urban areas.  
In view of the significant health cum nutritional, social, economic and environmental 
benefits, which generally can be associated with most existing aquaculture practices, and the 
good prospects for further development and expansion of the sector, it is important for efforts 
aiming at the sustainable development of aquaculture that potential social conflicts and 
environmental problems are minimized.  
A striking difference between aquaculture and more traditional aspects of fishery 
management according to Stickney (1979) is associated with degree of control exerted by 
man over the environment. Fishery managers attempt to manage natural aquatic ecosystems, 
usually for the benefit of sport or commercial fishermen. In general, the aquaculturist 
exercises much more control on the environment than the fishery manager. The aquaculturist 
manages water systems for maximum production of one or small number of species and 
attempts to eliminate insofar as possible all competition and sources of mortality.  
Aquaculture's contribution to global supplies of fish, crustaceans and molluscs continues 
to grow increasing from 3.9 percent of total production by weight in 1970 to 27.3 percent in 
2000 (FAO 2002) and 51.63 percent in 2005 (FAO 2006b). Absolute growth of aquaculture 
is more rapid than all other animal food producing sectors.  
During the past three decades, aquaculture has expanded, diversified, intensified and 
made technological advances. The potential of this development to enhance local food 
security, alleviate poverty and improve rural livelihoods has been well recognized. The need 
for the aquaculture sector to continue development towards its full potential, and making a 
net contribution to global food availability, domestic food security, economic growth, trade 
and improved living standards has been emphasised (FAO 2002).  
The ability of producing safer fish from aquaculture should become the next target in 
world fish production. This is possible because the water environment through which fish 
becomes tinted with chemicals and pollutants causing health concerns to man can be screened 
before use in aquaculture for fish production. 
 
 
5. Safe Fish Production in Controlled Environment  
 
FAO (1997) defines the term sustainable development as the management and 
conservation of the natural resource base and the orientation of technological and 
institutional change in such a manner as to ensure the attainment and continued satisfaction 
of human needs for present and future generations. Such sustainable development (in the 
agriculture, forestry and fisheries sectors) conserves land, water, plant and animal genetic 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Fish Consumption: A Paradox of Good Health 
87
resources, is environmentally non-degrading, technically appropriate, economically viable 
and socially acceptable.  
“Attainment and continued satisfaction of human needs” in fish production calls for 
producing fishes that may not predispose anyone to disease or ill health. Such fish is here 
referred to as “safe fish”. A situation where the sum total of fish contamination by deleterious 
chemicals cannot be completely isolated from the contamination in water the need to 
consciously use contamination free water in fish production has become paramount.  
Though the world has become aware of the intricacies of water pollution and 
contamination by heavy metals cum organic compounds, not so much has changed. The 
consciousness to produce safe fish should become ingrained in the mind of fish producers 
and in government policies. Aquaculture due to its peculiarity stands out as the only 
production system through which safe fish can be produced. There is the possibility of 
screening the production water source even before use. In this way contaminated water 
sources are not utilised but discarded. Policies should be formulated through world fisheries 
regulating bodies and governments to include safe fish production as a good aquaculture 
practice that can be enforced. 
The concept of safe fish production should be publicised and enforced. It can also be 
integrated into the Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries (CCRF). This code was 
development by FAO in consultation and collaboration with relevant United Nations 
Agencies and other international organizations, including non-governmental organizations. It 
was adopted by 31st October 2005. Article 9.1 of the code, deals with responsible 
development of aquaculture, including culture-based fisheries, in areas under national 
jurisdiction (FAO 1997). Safe fish production can become an integral part of responsible 
aquaculture practices. 
States were given the right under the code to designate or establish an authority or 
authorities competent, empowered and capable to effectively promote support and regulate 
aquaculture and culture-based fisheries. Appropriate institutional linkages with other 
authorities such as those concerned with agriculture, rural development, water resources, 
environment, health, education and training and many others, should also be established. 
These linkages may have to be expressed in legislative forms.  
In addition to appropriate regulation and control fish producers should understand the 
risk in consuming contaminated fish and thus decided to produce safe fish. The benefits will 
be enjoyed both by the fish producers and consumers.  
On the other hand world oceans, seas and rivers should be maintained for the benefit of 
man. Interestingly fisheries governance has been affected by the deliberations of the United 
Nations Conference on the Environment and Development (UNCED), held in 1992 in Rio de 
Janeiro, Brazil. Since that conference, the ecosystems dimensions of management issues have 
received increasing attention from governments, the UN system and the fishing industry. All 
are now more ready to recognize that fish are an integrated part of an aquatic ecosystem, a 
system in which modifications in one area have the potential to affect other areas. Thus, it is 
increasingly regarded as necessary, first to monitor the state of the aquatic ecosystem, and 
then to manage human interventions within that ecosystem. Only within such a framework 
will it be possible for capture fisheries to continue to be a source of food and income for 
future generations. In the coming years, humankind is likely to improve dramatically its 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Johnny O. Ogunji 
88 
understanding of the intricacies of aquatic ecosystems, and this will lead not only to more 
knowledge but also, and perhaps paradoxically, to growing uncertainties. As a result, there 
will be growing pressure for a strict application of the precautionary approach to all 
interventions, including those by fishers, in aquatic ecosystems. Both the aquaculture 
industry and the capture fisheries sector will realize that they must be seen by all concerned 
to respect this principle.

entries.full_text:
Chapter V 
 
 
Protein-Energy Wasting, Chronic 
Inflammation and PUFAS: Metabolic 
and Cardiovascular Risk in ESRD 
 
 
Gordana Perunicic-Pekovic¹, Zorica Rasic-Milutinovic¹, Sladjana 
Sobajic², Ivana Djuricic² and Radojka Maletic³ 
1Department of Nephrology and Endocrinology,  
2Faculty of Pharmacy,  
3Faculty of Agriculture,  
University Hospital Zemun, Belgrade, Serbia 
 
 
Abstract 
 
The patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) include significant percentage of 
malnourished patients together with other risk factors: dyslipoproteinaemia, insulin 
resistance, increased oxidative stress, inflammation, and they all together impair 
endothelial function.  
Nutrition, glicoregulation disorders and insulin resistance as etiologic factors 
participate a grate deal in premature atherosclerosis. Abnormal fatty acid patterns are 
reported in patients with such diseases as diabetes mellitus, inflammatory bowel disease, 
rheumatoid arthritis and atherosclerosis. Basic mechanism of these disorders is connected 
with changes in cells functions on the membrane level. These basic discoveries help us in 
understanding the damage process of endothelial and appearance of its dysfunction by 
inflammation process and by lipid peroxidation process.  
We examine association between atherosclerotic risk factors and nutritional status in 
hemodialysis patients. Our research is a part of the study in which haemodialysis patients 
will be followed. In our previous study we examined HD patients which were 
administered supplementation n-3 PUFAs for two months. Dietary regime with fish oil 
could be used in dialysis patients to slow down atherosclerosis process and improve 
nutritional parameters. 
Forty three hemodialysis patients were examined (20 males, 23 females, 55±12 
years). Nutritional and inflammatory markers-including serum concentrations of C-
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Gordana Perunicic-Pekovic, Zorica Rasic-Milutinovic, Sladjana Sobajic et al. 
94 
reactive protein, tumor necrosis factor alpha, and interleukin 6- were measured. Mortality 
was followed prospectively for up to 12 mo.  
Significant negative correlation between serum level of CRP and macroangiopathy 
was found. There was significant positive correlation between arachidonic acid (AA) and 
high sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP). Significant correlation was found between 
body mass index (BMI) and n-3 fatty acids.  
Increasing inflammation and endothelial dysfunction predict the development of 
vascular disease. We report the relationship between inflammatory markers and 
nutritional parameters indices of atherosclerosis and other cardiovascular risk factors in 
patients on hemodialysis. 
 
 
Keywords: malnutrition, inflammation, hemodialysis, PUFAs

entries.excerpt: Introduction    Malnutrition and inflammation are associated with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
entries.full_text:
Introduction 
 
Malnutrition and inflammation are associated with end-stage renal disease (ESRD). 
Interleukin (IL-6) and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α) powerfully predict death from 
cardiovascular disease in dialysis patients as well as progression of vascular injury. 
Atherosclerosis and inflammation have similar basic mechanisms involving the adhesion of 
leukocytes to vascular endothelium in their early phases. Major predictors of clinical outcome 
in dialysis patients are protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) and inflammation. A common 
mechanism for the development of cardiovascular disease and malnutrition in dialysis 
patients may be cytokine activation.[1,2,3,4]  
Many studies were examined inflammatory markers in process endothelial dysfunction. 
Inflammatory state in end stage renal disease (ESRD) are associated with an elevation of 
serum acute phase proteins, including CRP and some pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-
6 and TNF alpha. IL-6 is reported to play a central role in the pathophysiology of adverse 
effects of inflammation in ESRD patients. Increased activation of inflammatory cytokines, 
such as IL-6 and TNF-alpha, may cause muscle breakdown and hypoalbuminemia, and may 
be involved in atherogenesis.[5,6,7,8,9,10] 
Dyslipidemia is one of the possible risk factors for advanced atherosclerosis in patients 
with chronic renal failure. Abnormal phospholipid metabolism may play an important role in 
the progression of atherosclerosis in patients with renal failure. The total concentration of 
serum non-esterified fatty acids (NEFA) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of 
cardiovascular disease (CVD). Individual circulating NEFA have achieved less scientific 
focus in relation to atherosclerosis compared to total NEFA. A strong link exists between 
chronic inflammation and nutritional markers in hemodialysis (HD) patients. Biological 
effects of n-3 fatty acids have been shown in studies of animals and humans in which anti-
inflammatory and antithrombotic effects could be of relevance in HD patients. It is widely 
accepted that dietary intake of n-3 PUFA or fish and fish oil as their dietary sources have 
beneficial health effects among sick and healthy individuals. A great number of clinical 
studies have shown that intake of n-3 fatty acids reduces incidence of cardiovascular events 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Protein-Energy Wasting, Chronic Inflammation and PUFAS 
95
and play an important role in the prevention of inflammatory and autoimmune 
disorders.[11,12,13,14]  
HD patients have impaired essential fatty acid status (EFA), as well as high level of 
oxidative stress, and very often are malnourished with a high risk for developing 
cardiovascular pathology. 
First aim of our study was to establish the association between markers of inflammation 
and atherosclerosis with parameters of malnutrition in HD patients. Second aim of this study 
was to determine the baseline status of EFA in middle-aged hemodialysis patients and within 
the average middle-aged population in Serbia (healthy control), using the FA composition of 
erythrocyte total lipids as a reliable parameter of cellular EFA status.Baseline values 
confirmed the presence of EFA deficiency in HD patients in comparison with the healthy 
control. 
 
 
Methods 
 
The University Clinical Research Ethics Committee approved the study. All 42 
haemodialysis patients, recruited from our unit gave written informed consent. They had been 
treated with hemodialysis three times a week for at least 6 months. The patients with 
diabetes, acute infections and malignancy were excluded from the study. The duration of 
dialysis was defined as the number of months from initiation of chronic hemodialysis to the 
time of laboratory data collection. All blood samples were obtained immediately before the 
dialysis session after an 8-hour fast on a mid-week dialysis session. Plasma levels of albumin, 
transferin, interleukin-6 (IL-6), tumor necrosis factor – alpha (TNF-α), high sensitivity C-
reactive protein (hs-CRP), total cholesterol, triglyceride, HDL-cholesterol, and LDL 
cholesterol were measured. Plasma albumin, transferrin and lipids were measured by routine 
laboratory methods. Plasma hs-CRP level, TNF-α and IL-6 were measured by enzyme-linked 
immunosorbent assay kits (ELISA). Body mass index (BMI) was recorded. Lean body mass 
(LBM), was measured by bioelectric impedance (BIA). Mid-arm muscle circumference 
(MAMC) was recorded too.We used standard Doppler echo examinations to determine 
plaque on carotid arteries. End diastolic pressure (EDD) and ejection fraction (EF) were 
measured by echocardiography.  
The total fatty acids composition was determined by gas chromatography (GS) in the 
methyl esters form.GS analysis was performed on a VARIAN chromatographer, Model 1400. 
All statistical analysis was made with Stat 6.0 software package on MS Windows 
(Statsoft Inc., Novi Sad Serbia). The t-test and Mann-Whitney test were applied for statistical 
comparisons between groups and for statistical comparisons before and after treatment in HD 
patients. Pearson s correlation analysis was used to study correlations between variables. 
Statistical multivariate factor analysis of the results was carried out to investigate all 
parametes. The objective of factor analysis was to reveal a simple underlying structure that is 
presumed to exist within a set of multivariate observations.  
 
 
 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Gordana Perunicic-Pekovic, Zorica Rasic-Milutinovic, Sladjana Sobajic et al. 
96 
Results 
 
The main results of the patients of each tertile are shown on the Table 1. HD patients of 
the 3rd tertile, representing 30% of the whole group, presented LBM levels indicative of a 
well nourished group. These patients presented BMI and other nutritional parameters, 
significantly higher than that of the patients in the 1st tertile. IL-6 and TNF-α were higher in 
the patients in the 1st tertile and these differences were significantly according to 3st tertile. 
Patients with a lower LBM values had decreased BMI, MAMC, albumin level and transferrin 
level than those in the higher tertile. Malnourished patients had significantly increased 
cardiovascular disease and carotid plaques. Risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorder 
was greater when serum albumin concentration was lower.  
Significant positive correlation between TNF-alpha and LDL/HDL cholesterol was found 
in the whole group of HD patients (Table 2). Parameter of inflammatory process, hs-CRP was 
positive correlation with atherosclerotic and cardiovascular parameters. There were negative 
correlation with hs-CRP and albumin and HDL-cholesterol level (Table 3).  
There was negative correlation between mid-arm muscle circumference (MAMC) and 
albumin level and saturated fatty acids. There was positive correlation between diastolic 
blood pressure and n-3PUFA (Table 6 and 7). 
The results showed the total content of the n-3 fatty acids (3.02±0.84 to 3.91±1.01), as 
well as the total content of the polyunsaturated fatty acids (24.2±3.16 to 29.5±3.87), 
significantly increased after fish oil supplementation in HD patients. The significant decrease 
was observed in total saturated fatty acids content (45.7±3.06 to 41.6±4.47), while content of 
total monounsaturated fatty acids was not changed. A decrease in plasma triglyceride but not 
significantly and a significant increase in plasma HDL-cholesterol concentrations were 
observed after fish oil supplementation (Table 4). 
After 8 weeks of fish oil supplementation, the status of most individual erythrocyte FAs 
was not significantly changed in healthy control. The only significant changed were the 
decrease in oleic acid, 20:3 n-9 FAs and the ratio of n-6/n-3. Noticed increase in EPA and 
DHA was not statistically significant. After fish oil supplementation concentrations of plasma 
trigliceride and total cholesterol were significant decreased, but no significant effects in 
plasma HDL-cholesterol concentration was observed (Table 5). 
Results of the factor analysis indicated 4 latent factors that explained 66.94% of the 
variance within all investigated parameters (Table 8). The 1st factor of all parameters 
explained 21.96% of the variance. The highest factor loadings were found at the positive end 
for triglyceride, cholesterol and LDL cholesterol level as the atherogenic factor. Significant 
factor loadings for the 2nd factor, with 16.51% of the explained variance, had the components 
of IL-6 and TNF-alpha at the positive end for these parameters, as inflammatory parmeters. 
The 3rd factor, with 14.76% of the explained variance, had one component with high factor 
loadings, namely, LBM as a nutritional parameter parameter. The presence of factor 4 with 
13.71% of explained varience had both  hs-CRP level and albumin level as factors at the 
positive ends and these are two parameters indicative of an inflammatory process and 
malnutrition.

Protein-Energy Wasting, Chronic Inflammation and PUFAS

entries.full_text:
Fish Oil Supplements 
 
Many people have turned to fish oil supplements to get adequate omega-3 fatty acids. 
Evidence from several studies has suggested that amounts of DHA and EPA in the form of 
fish or fish oil supplements lowers triglycerides, slows the buildup of atherosclerotic plaques 
lowers blood pressure slightly, as well as reduces the risk of death, heart attack, dangerous 
abnormal heart rhythms, and strokes in people with known heart disease. However, high 
doses may have harmful effects, such as an increased risk of bleeding. Although similar 
benefits are proposed for alpha-linolenic acid, scientific evidence is less compelling, and 
beneficial effects may be less pronounced [69]. Fish oil supplements have sometimes come 
under scrutiny in recent years. In early 2006, government agencies such as the Food 
Standards Agency in the UK and the Food Safety Authority of Ireland reported PCB levels 
that exceeded the strict new European maximum limits in several fish oil brands, which 
required temporary withdrawal of these brands. 
Risks and benefits of fish and fish oil supplement consumptions need to be carefully 
evaluated before recommending any further changes to the diet in the US and around the 
world. While anyone can be harmed by high levels of mercury that can be found in fish like 
shark, some population groups are especially vulnerable to mercury and should consult their 
healthcare providers before consuming large amounts of fish that is known to contain 
mercury. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reports that people most 
sensitive to mercury are pregnant and nursing women, children under the age of six 
(especially up to the age of three), people with impaired kidney function, and those with very 
sensitive immune responses to metals. 
Future studies in this area should concentrate on examining the longitudinal changes in 
serum concentrations of cancer related biomarkers in relation to fish consumption. 
Geographic variation in fish consumption, type of fish consumed, and cooking styles, needs 
to be incorporated in these investigations. This data could be potentially investigated in 
relation to cancer incidence, treatment response, relapse, complications, and survival. 
 
 
 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Faina Linkov, Barbara Stadterman and Emanuela Taioli 
124 
Methods 
 
Search and selection of literature. A systematic literature search of publications on fish 
consumption and cancer development has been performed using Pubmed search engine. The 
following terms have been used in the database searches for studies on fish consumption and 
cancer development: fish, diet, risk factors, nutrition, fish. The criteria for inclusion of studies 
in the review were as follows: case control or cohort studies investigating the association 
between fish consumption and cancer development, and were published in English or had an 
expanded abstract in English.  
In the area of biologic markers, all papers dealing with serum and plasma markers 
investigated in relation to fish consumption and cancer have been evaluated. The following 
terms have been used in the database searches for studies on endometrial cancer biomarkers: 
fish consumption, biomarkers, serum, plasma, inflammatory markers. The bibliographic lists 
of relevant publications were hand searched to identify additional useful articles. Articles 
were excluded if they had <10 cancer cases included in the analysis and if they were not full 
length research publications. Figure 3 outlines the article selection steps utilized in this study. 
Data extraction. The data were extracted and analyzed by the authors of this review. 
Study size, study type, study population, methodology, and key findings were documented 
and reported in table 1. Our biomarker review did not include research articles exploring fish 
oil supplements, as those were evaluated in detail by MacLean and colleagues in a systematic 
review recently published in JAMA[26]. 
 
 
Results 
 
The largest body of literature exists for prostate, breast, colorectal, and lung cancer in 
relation to fish consumption (between 30 and 90 articles per cancer). Limited literature is 
available for aerodigestive, endometrial, bladder, lymphoma, ovarian, pancreatic, skin, and 
stomach cancer. Basic developments in the fields of various cancers and fish consumptions 
were summarized in the next parts of this chapter. Table 1 summarizes findings in the area of 
cancer biomarkers.

Emerging Health Risk Due 
to Shellfish Consumption? 
 
 
Juan Martínez-Hernández∗,1, 2, Victoria Lopez-Rodas2

entries.full_text:
Chapter IX 
 
 
Emerging Health Risk Due 
to Shellfish Consumption? 
 
 
Juan Martínez-Hernández∗,1, 2, Victoria Lopez-Rodas2 
 and Eduardo Costas2 
1 Servicio de Medicina Preventiva y Salud Pública. Hospital Carlos III  
28029, Madrid, Spain 
2Genética, Facultad de Veterinaria, Universidad Complutense,  
28040, Madrid, Spain 
 
 
Abstract 
 
Shellfish is one of the main commercial productions in aquaculture industry of USA, 
Europe, Japan and China. Since shellfish feed by filtration, often they accumulate (bio-) 
toxins, bacteria, and parasites. As a result thousands people suffered Paralytic-, Amnesic-
, or Diarrheic Shellfish Poisoning (PSP, ASP, DSP), ciguatera and other diseases during 
the twentieth century (and as consequence many people died). Relevant efforts have been 
made in prevention programs, treatments and legislation to reduce the incidence of such 
diseases (usually obtaining satisfactory results).  
However, new emerging health problems are being linked to shellfish consumption. 
For example, mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis) and cockles (Cerastoderma edule) store 
infectious Cryptosporidium parvum oocyst, which produce diarrhea in humans (being a 
relevant cause of died in AIDS infected people). On the other hand, European legislation 
allows less than 0,16μg DSP toxin (okadaic acid equivalent) per gram of meat (Decision 
2002/225/CE), which is enough to prevent Diarrheic Shellfish Poisoning. In spite of this, 
DSP toxins are also potent tumor promoters. An epidemiological study shows a 
statistically significant correlation (p<0.001) between consumption of molluscs and the 
incidence of colorectal cancer (an increase of 7 times in shellfish consumption produced 
                                                 
 
∗ Corresponding Address: Dr. Juan Martínez Hernández, Servicio de Medicina Preventiva, Hospital Carlos III, c/ 
Sinesio 
Delgado 
10, 
28029 
Madrid 
(Spain). 
jmartinez.hciii@salud.madrid.org, 
+34660632167, 
+34914532611. 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Juan Martínez-Hernández, Victoria Lopez-Rodas and Eduardo Costas 
158 
duplication in the risk ratio of colorectal cancer. Many other risks have not been taken in 
account. For instance, shellfish from estuaries can accumulate microcystins (potent 
hepatotoxins) produced by freshwater cyanobacteria transported to the estuary by the 
river. Microcystins have been implicated in the high rates of hepatic cancer in China 
population.  
As a conclusion, a lot of work is still necessary to assure a safety in shellfish 
consumption. 
 
 
An important and ongrowing nourishing source is Shellfish. Represents a protein source 
(11.9% of the edible portion of the mussel is protein) quite a low calorie foodstuff (86 
Kcal/100g of the edible portion of the mussel) and is high in Iodine, selenium and Vitamin 
A[1]. 
Is a product with a high profitability; probably is the group of foodstuffs from marine 
origin with more added value in relation with its production costs. 
Furthermore, in Spain aquaculture is strongly backed by the authorities (Galicia, in 
Spain, is the top region in the European rank of shellfish producers, producing regularly 
250,000T of mussels, only bested by China with approximately 450,000T per annum) 
amongst other reasons for these being is that this allows the stability and the traditional ways 
of life of the communities linked to the sea. 
It is a general belief that is recommended to evolve from an extractive society to an 
intensive fish-farming one. However, intensifying marine fishery has its own risks and 
disadvantages, especially if we consider that this animals feed by filtrating the plankton 
present in the seawater and in the estuaries. 
Residues from small villages -in which having a water-purification plant for the sewage 
water is not compulsory- go directly to the seawater or to the estuary. Also main rivers carry 
in their waters the legal and illegal dumping into the stream of substances. There is also 
pouring of substances coming from the aquaculture activities, the cleansing of the bilge of 
vessels and the naval accidents. Sadly, not an uncommon event. Like those of the oil tankers 
Exxon Valdez (Alaska, 1999) or Prestige (Galicia, 2002). 
Chemical substances in the water can be of great importance because they affect to life 
and reproduction of molluscs and also because these substances can bio-accumulate in the 
muscle and the hepatopancreas of the animal. This will be the case for the chlorinated organic 
compounds like the polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)[2] that is widely used although an illegal 
substance, among other reasons because of its long lasting toxic effect, agricultural 
pesticides[3], dioxins[4], benzopyrene[5] and other polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons from 
fires, burning of cereal stubble or incineration of residues, that can be accumulated in the 
animal’s fat[6]. 
Toxic substances affect not only culture species but also wild ones: PCBs can induce an 
increase of the male population consequently damaging the preservation of the wild species. 
Heavy metals (lead, cadmium and mercury for example) are equally absorbed by the 
mollusks[7] and can accumulate them in the edible part and in the shell, with the subsequent 
risk if these shells are used to extract the calcium for pharmaceutical use in humans or 
livestock or to reinforce food. In fact, mussels also accumulate beneficial oligoelements in 
low doses like selenium. 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Emerging Health Risk Due to Shellfish Consumption? 
159
The risk of neurotoxicity in people eating fish or shellfish is significantly higher if metals 
like mercury for example, go through an organification process to methylmercury (remember 
the 1953 outbreak in Minamata Bay, Japan[8, 9]). 
Equally, some microorganisms like Vibrio parahaemolyticus can poison the meat of 
bivalves and be the reason for diarrhoea if consumed raw or partially cooked[10]. Cysts of 
the small parasite Cryptosporidium parvum can be retained in shellfish[11]. If consumed by 
healthy people it can cause diarrhoea and in patients with AIDS chronic diarrhoea. 
Biotoxins produced by algae and dinoflagelate must be considered apart due to its 
severity, its progressive increase in relation with climate change and its possible long-term 
effect. Following is a brief description of the toxicity of the main chemical species 
recognized to date, in animal models and in-vitro cultures 
It is important to emphasize that the syndromes recognized to date due to shellfish 
poisoning in relation with verified human health problems are mainly acute. These are PSP 
(Paralytic Shellfish Poisoning), ASP (Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning), NSP (Neurotoxic 
Shellfish Poisoning), and DSP (Diarrheic Shellfish Poisonig).  
All of them are diagnosed clinically by the knowledge of bivalve consumption in the 
previous 24 hours. This is because we lack of biomarkers that confirm the exposure to the 
toxins. We also lack an antitoxin and treatment is symptomatic and life support based. 
The most common toxic syndrome of marine biotoxins is ciguatera. It is related to the 
consumption in tropical regions of barracuda and other big fishes that can accumulate 
ciguatoxin. 
Intoxication with tetrodotoxin (associated with the consumption of pufferfish in 
Japan[12], and maybe done on purpose in voodoo acts in Haiti[13]) will not be considered in 
this chapter dedicated to shellfish. 
We will neither consider the intoxication with gempylotoxin due to escolar and oilfish 
consumption, or the scombrotoxin, that forms in fish after captured and kept without chilling, 
this causes the bacteria to attack the histidin and change it into histamine (histamine 
poisoning)[14]. 
Although it has been of interest the acute nature of the these intoxications, evidences are 
increasingly gathered that show that lipidic and thermoresistant biotoxins, like okadaic acid 
and its derivatives, could be retained for long periods and even establish an enterohepatic 
recirculation cycle. 
In theory, there is a possibility that DSP toxins can be less toxic if consumed in quantities 
above the legal limit, in this case they will be virtually totally eliminated by the mild and self-
limiting diarrhoeic syndrome itself. If consumed below the limit, the toxin will accumulate in 
the body fat and circulate now and again, with the subsequent cytotoxic damage, mutagen 
effect and above all luminal tumour promoter over premalign lesions like the colon polyps. In 
fact, it is known from old observations that cathartic agents used in the first half of 20th 
century, compounds made from mercury called calomel, were very poisonous when 
consumed in low doses and innocuous if taken at the laxative dose, because they were totally 
removed. 
To achieve a correct diagnose a hypothetic biomarker should be sought. Preferably in 
urine because toxic substances that accumulate in the bile usually are eliminated in the faeces 
or via kidneys as glucuroconjugates. 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Juan Martínez-Hernández, Victoria Lopez-Rodas and Eduardo Costas 
160 
As a hypothesis, and with some preliminary epidemiological data available, okadaic acid 
and its derivatives is a new risk factor for the large bowel cancer[15,16] and maybe for other 
digestive tract tumors[17]. 
 
 
PSP (Paralytic Shellfish Poisoning) 
 
There are approximately 27 known toxins with the capability to cause PSP. Saxitoxin 
(STX) is a non-sulphated variation and the most powerful of tem all. In sea water it is 
produced by dinoflagellates while in fresh water cianobacteria can produce it. Other PSP 
toxins are the gonyautoxins (GTX). 
Signs and symptoms are predominantly neurologic and include tingling, burns, 
numbness, sleepiness, disjointed speech, and respiratory paralysis that can cause death. All of 
this commences between half an hour and two hours after consuming the contaminated food 
and generally disappears after 12 hours unless an acute respiratory failure scenario appears 
and is not properly treated in hospital or a cardiac arrest due to hypotension. 
It is very illustrative of the clinical presentation[18] an episode well described, as the one 
that took place in Alaska the 6th of June 1990, when 6 fishermen consumed some mussels 
well cooked. Between one and two hours after eating, 5 of them felt some numbness in the 
mouth, two of them tingling in the tongue and one numbness in the throat. Four of the 
fishermen threw up and four had paresthesia in the limbs. All of them were seen in the 
emergency unit of a hospital. Two of them required several day hospitalizations, but in the 
end all of them recovered from the episode. The toxin was present in the raw mussels in a 
higher concentration than in the cooked (during 90 minutes) ones. This is consistent with the 
fact that is a hydrosoluble and thermoresistant substance that was partially diluted in the 
stock. 
Previously there was a terrible incident in the pacific coast of Guatemala, in Champerico, 
between July and August 1987. 187 people got sick of PSP and 26 died (14%)[19]. The death 
rate among children under 6 was 50% and amongst over 18 was 7%, probably due to a less 
distribution volume of the toxin in children. It was related to the consumption of a wild clam 
Amphichaena kindermani harvested in the beaches. Probably many lives could have been 
saved with intensive care in these patients. 
In the northeast coast of Margarita island, between August and October 1991 there was 
an important bloom of dinoflagellates Prorocentrum gracile, Gymnodinium catenatum and 
Alexandrium tamarense that caused 24 cases of PSP from which 16 required hospitalization. 
The concentration of saxitoxin in mussels (Perna perna) exceeded significantly the 
considered safe level of 80 µg per gram of meat[20]. 
Episodes of PSP can occur in conjunction with other intoxications[21], as was discovered 
after analysing the samples obtained from a red tide occurred in Galicia, Spain in 1993, 
where it was found STX, GTX2, GTX3 and diarrhoeic toxins jointly. 
PSP would probably be the biggest acute toxicity problem in this type of foodstuff if 
shellfish from producing areas were not controlled as they are. 
Even in 2003, in a study in Shanghay markets, 8 out of 66 samples had saxitoxin and 
where positive to mouse bioassay[22]. 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Emerging Health Risk Due to Shellfish Consumption? 
161
ASP (Amnesic Shellfish Poisoning) 
 
Several algae species, especially diatomea of the genus Pseudo-nitzschia produce a 
tricarboxilic aminoacid analogous to glutamate called domoic acid capable of serious 
intoxications. 
It seems that his action is exerted by the glutamate receptors like the one for kainite, 
another excitative aminoacid, especially of the hippocampus area[23]. In the next 24 hours 
after eating the contaminated molluscs gastrointestinal symptoms of moderate importance 
start, and the mental symptoms in 48 hours. The neurodegenerative effect is seen principally 
as loss of the short-term memory, if recovered it takes a long time, resembling in some way to 
Alzheimer disease, but hallucinations, coma, and death can also occur. Elderly people are 
especially sensible and all the deaths registered where in this group of age. 
In 1987 in Prince Edwards Island (Canada) more than 150 people were intoxicated and 4 
died after eating mussels contaminated with domoic acid[24]. 
Domoic acid was first detected in molluscs in 1998 in Scotland[25] and France[26], and 
in 1999 in Ireland[27], with a particularly high content in the scallops (Pecten maximus) 
harvested in the east and south coast of the Republic of Ireland (2,820 micrograms per gram 
of the edible portion). In 2003 and 2004 in Scotland ASP toxins where the most frequent 
biotoxins in shellfish, found in 69% of the samples in one study[28]. 
Domoic acid can enter the trofic chain and bioaccumulate in the viscera of Sepia 
officinalis[29], and transfer to marine mammals that feed on them and probably to other 
cephalopoda, but it does not affect the mantle and because of that toxicity in humans is not 
expectable, unless young animals from this species are consumed without evisceration, what 
happens in certain cultures. Deaths in pelicans and sea lions have been registered along side 
the west coast of the United States in the 90´s. Whales feed on fish and cephalopoda that are 
contaminated with domoic acid[30], and to date there are no data about toxicity in this 
animals. 
In Europe and Canada[31] the total content of Amnesic Shellfish Poison (ASP) in the 
edible parts of molluscs (the entire body or any edible part separately) must not exceed 20 
micrograms of domoic acid per gram using the HPLC method.  
A control system model in Chile, keeps watch on the presence of Psudonitzchia 
australis[32]. The meat of the molluscs is controlled if in the phitoplanckton samples the 
algae goes above the 65%. If the level of domoic acid rises over 5 micrograms per gram, the 
extraction area is closed and the molluscs and phitoplanckton is intensively controlled. 
 
 
NSP (Neurotoxic Shellfish Poisoning) 
 
Gymnodinium breve (Karenia brevis) is a marine dinoflagellate that produce brevetoxins, 
the potent toxins that cause neurotoxic shellfish poisoning[33]. The effects of brevetoxins are 
not only seen after consumption, but they also have the striking attribute of toxicity by 
contact with the conjunctival, oropharyngeal and respiratory tract mucosae, causing irritation 
and allergies. Occasionally they can cause bronchospasm and asmatic crises[34]. 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Juan Martínez-Hernández, Victoria Lopez-Rodas and Eduardo Costas 
162 
In the Genoa outbreak between the 17th and 26th of July 2005, 205 patients were seen in 
the emergency units (maybe the number was even higher but they did not require specific 
medic care). An inclusion criterion was to be present in the vicinity of the coast during the 
bloom. They had fever (64%), sore throat (50%), cough (40%), and in less amount dyspnea, 
cephalalgy, rhinorrea and vomits. 20% required hospitalization but in the majority of them 
the symptoms disappeared spontaneously in few hours. Average delay in the onset of 
symptoms was 7 hours, varying from 30 minutes to 23 hours. 
In this event bloom was originated by Ostreopsis ovata that produce palytoxin. It is one 
of the strongest nonpeptidic toxins. Causes cytolysis as a result of the inhibition of Na+, K+-
ATPase and has been recognised as the causative agent of fatal human seafood 
poisoning[36]. 
 
 
DSP (Diarrhetic Shellfish Poisonig) 
 
Depending on the amount of okadaic acid (OA) or its derivates, dinophysistoxins 
(DTXs), pectenotoxins (PTXs), azaspiracids (AZAs), yessotoxins (YTXs), spirolides (SPXs) 
and gymnodimines (GYMs) ingested, within 30 minutes and 3 hours after, a self-limiting 
diarrhoea condition starts. Generally it does not require special care and precisely because of 
this is frequently under diagnosed. 
Okadaic acid is a highly soluble in lipids polyether, thermoresistant and with an irritating 
and cytotoxic action. This is why it persists in preserved or cooked shellfish. Furthermore, it 
is a strong tumour promoter. It is unknown the long term effect of the toxin capable of being 
retained in the body fat, although there is some evidence about its effect as a risk factor in the 
colon cancer[12, 14]. 
In Europe, the amount considered safe to prevent DSP is 0.16 grams per gram of edible 
portion of the mollusk[37]. However, these limits are often surpassed in other parts of the 
globe, and in countries with control systems in place, like Spain, the detected levels can be 
close to the limit. The limit is established because is the one in the mouse bioassay; below 
this level it could only be detected by means of more sensible procedures like ELISA or 
HPLC. The Bioassay must continue to be the diagnostic reference to detect presence of toxins 
in molluscs because it is very unspecific; it will detect any new toxin without loosing 
sensibility, especially if other assays are performed to confirm and to be more precise in 
detecting toxins. 
Control systems are more efficient if they focus in monitoring microorganisms that 
produce toxins. The absence of the toxic dinoflagellate implies the absence of toxin. Control 
systems based in detecting toxins must consider that some of these (the liposoluble ones) can 
have long-term toxic effect developed only in sensitive people due to hereditary factors and 
in foetus and breast-feeding babies (certainly is excreted this via). Although this is so far only 
a theoretical possibility, the best safe level for DSP toxins is the absence of toxin, and this 
can be guaranteed with good control systems. 
 
 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Emerging Health Risk Due to Shellfish Consumption? 
163
Global Change, Marine Aquacultures 
and Biotoxins 
 
The argument that extractive way of life must be necessarily changed to another mainly 
based on intensive fish farming is basically false, because the farmed fish and shellfish need 
primarily marine foodstuffs originated from extractive systems. Further more, extractive 
systems have an impact on the environment not only because of the freedom of specimens but 
also because of pollutants released into the ocean. Extractive fishery is environmentally 
sustainable if done in a regulated way and knowing the quantities present of the commercial 
species and adapting to them, with the biological stops that are recommended. 
Intensive mussel culture in batea is a production that has to progress with special 
attention to security and quality. For so, care and respect to the environment has to be 
optimum. Increasingly contaminated estuaries cannot produce better quality molluscs 
although they produce more quantity. Safer products reinforce the consumer security and 
increase the added value of the product. Excessive increases in productions always affect 
prices negatively. 
 Water eutrofization due to rises in water temperature and to spillages rich in phosphates 
certainly increase red tides, not only in means of occurrence, but also in duration and 
intensity, with an increase in the days that extraction is banned in the shellfish producer 
regions. 
These foodstuffs are natural or antropogenic toxin and metal concentrators, and its 
consumption must be promoted as something occasional, not on a daily basis or as a basic 
nutrient.

Clinical Experience with Fish Oil Based

Despite evidence to the contrary in a variety of animal models, there is still skepticism 
regarding the ability of parenteral fish oil to prevent EFAD and maintain adequate growth
