entries.excerpt: Clinical Experience with Fish Oil Based  Lipid Emulsions
entries.full_text:
Clinical Experience with Fish Oil Based 
Lipid Emulsions  
 
Despite evidence to the contrary in a variety of animal models, there is still skepticism 
regarding the ability of parenteral fish oil to prevent EFAD and maintain adequate growth 
rate when used as monotherapy. Recent reports suggest that the omega-3 fatty acids, alpha-
linolenic acid (ALA), EPA, and DHA, which are present in fish oil, might play a role in 
reducing the amount of the omega-6 fatty acid, linoleic acid required to prevent EFAD.[40] 
Omegaven® (Fresenius Kabi Deutschland GmbH, Bad Homburg v.d.H., Germany) is the 
only commercially available lipid emulsion that contains solely fish oils. In 2005, Gura et al. 
described the first case in which Omegaven® was used as the sole intravenous lipid source in 
a human.41 Due to a severe soy allergy, this patient was unable to tolerate any parenteral fat 
emulsion commercially available in the United States. The patient had gone to develop 
biochemical evidence of EFAD accompanied by truncal folliculitis over a course of months 
secondary to fat free PN in the absence of any enteral feedings and despite topical oil therapy. 
[41] After receiving emergency FDA approval, Omegaven® was administered and resulted in 
resolution of the rash in 10 days and normalization of essential fatty acid status after 17 days.  
Since this case report and based on the results of the previously described murine studies, 
Omegaven® monotherapy has been used Children's Hospital Boston since 2004 under an 
FDA approved compassionate treatment protocol for PN-dependent patients with cholestasis. 
In one early case report, 2 pediatric patients with cholestasis due to PNALD were treated 
with Omegaven® and their serum bilirubin levels normalized within 60 days. [42] Both 
infants tolerated the therapy well and did not experience any adverse reactions. Based on 
these initial findings, more than 100 children with PNALD with the fish oil-based lipid 
emulsion have been similarly treated. In March 2008, a comprehensive analysis was 
published in which the outcome of the first 18 patients on Omegaven® monotherapy [43] 
was compared to a group of 21 historical controls who received the conventional soybean oil-
based lipid emulsions.11 Children who received Omegaven® monotherapy experienced 
reversal of cholestasis approximately 7 times faster than the historical controls, effectively 
halting the progression of PNALD. This gave the children time to develop enteral tolerance 
and transition to full enteral feedings. In this study, 2 children receiving Omegaven® died 
from causes unrelated to its use, whereas mortality related to PNALD was 29% in the 
historical cohort. Moreover, 2 infants receiving parenteral soy bean-based lipid emulsions 
underwent a liver transplantation, compared to no liver transplants in the Omegaven® oil 
treated patients. Furthermore, Omegaven® monotherapy was not associated with EFAD, 
hypertriglyceridemia, coagulopathy, bloodstream infections, or growth impairment. Since the 
publication of these reports, several other centers have experience similar dramatic findings. 
[44, 45] 
 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Kathleen M. Gura

entries.excerpt: Background    Cereals, of the taxonomic family Gramineae, are responsible for a high rate of allergic
entries.full_text:
Background 
 
Cereals, of the taxonomic family Gramineae, are responsible for a high rate of allergic 
and immunologic reactions [1,2]. Cereals include wheat, barley, rye, oats, rice and maize, and 
different consumption patterns of various cereals around the world may justify the different 
rates of sensitization reported for each cereal [1]. They are the major components of the 
human diet in many countries around the world, and sensitization to any of the cereals 
consequently represents a major public health challenge. In many countries, corn (Zea mays 
L) is the basic ingredient of frequently eaten foods like porridge, polenta, corn flakes, 
popcorn, tacos, chips, canned de-embryonated kernels, and other food products. Corn is also 
component of products used in the elaboration of bread, cakes and beer. In addition, corn 
may be used in the elaboration of starch, glue, cosmetics, stickers, stamp adhesives, exipients 
(for example, in the formulations of aspirin and vitamins), chewing gum, talcum powder, 
lozenges, ointments, toothpastes, laxatives and bath powder [3] 
The protein composition of maize seeds has been investigated in depth. However, few 
studies have addressed the identification of maize allergens. A major lipid transfer protein 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
Copyright © 2009. Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated. All rights reserved.

Kathleen M. Gura 
178 
(LTP) allergen of maize appears to be a protein belonging to group 1 of grass pollen allergens 
that are responsible for seasonal respiratory symptoms [4]; the maize allergen appears to be 
responsible for provoking food-induced allergen reactions. Similar to flour, particles of corn 
can also be inhaled by people handling it while making cakes, pastry cooks, by housewives 
and by farmers [4]. Corn flour contains about 7% to 13% protein that can be fractionated into 
several solubility classes; the salt-extractable fraction (albumins and globulins) averages less 
than 4% of the total endosperm protein and mainly comprises of proteins with metabolic 
functions whereas 60-70% of proteins are called zeins [5].  
Corn is often cited as an allergenic food and positive specific IgE to this cereal have been 
reported. In Mexico, despite the high consumption pattern of corn, there is only limited 
information on food-induced allergic reactions to maize in adults [6]. Symptoms may include 
urticaria, diarrhea, wheezing, and in some cases anaphylaxis [7]. Therefore, we performed the 
present study in order to evaluate specific IgE levels as a diagnostic test of corn allergy in 
children.

Patients and Methods 
 
In a prospective study design, 41 consecutive pediatric patients between the age of 9 
months and 11.5 years (median 2.3), with history of urticaria, atopic dermatitis, vomiting,

entries.excerpt: Patients and Methods    In a prospective study design, 41 consecutive pediatric patients between the age of 9
entries.full_text:
Patients and Methods 
 
In a prospective study design, 41 consecutive pediatric patients between the age of 9 
months and 11.5 years (median 2.3), with history of urticaria, atopic dermatitis, vomiting, 
diarrhea, abdominal pain, rhinitis, or wheezing after ingesting corn, were included in the 
study. Specific IgE levels were obtained from all children and food oral challenges to maize 
was performed as follows. Blood samples were obtained before the oral challenge to maize 
and specific IgE levels to corn were obtained by means of the Pharmacia CAP System FEIA 
(Pharmacia Diagnostics AB, Uppsala, Sweden). 
Food challenges to maize were performed in adherence to the EAACI guidelines and 
following protocols reported elsewhere [8-11]. Starting from a dosage of 0.5 g, food dose was 
double every 20 minutes until the entire meal was eaten or until symptoms appeared. The 
maximum dosage was 100 g. The sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive 
values (PPV and NPV, respectively) were obtained for specific IgE were obtained using the 
food challenge as a gold standard. Receiver-operator characteristics (ROC) curves were also 
constructed. Area under the curve (AUC) was calculated to quantify the accuracy of the 
single test and to compare the diagnostic value.  
 
 
Results  
 
There were 25 boys (60.9%) and 16 were girls (39.1%). The diagnostic challenge test 
positive in 29 children (70%). Of them, 29 (70%) had wheezing, 16 (39%) atopic dermatitis 
(10 points of SCORAD), 10 (24%) diarrhea, and 8 (19.5%) urticaria. In the analysis of the 
ROC curve, the optimal decision point of IgE was 7.5 Ku/L with a negative predictive value 
of 80%, positive predictive value 66%, sensitivity 96%, and specificity 77%.  
 
 
Fish Consumption and Health, edited by George P. Gagne, and Richard H. Medrano, Nova Science Publishers, Incorporated, 2009. ProQuest Ebook
